content:
Nice simple clash, but "Can you handle it?" and "Validator 6" are both against the spirit of the statement by adding the unnecessary leading zeroes to the inputs. You don't mention this anywhere in the statement and specify that the inputs will be space-separated *integers*, so it seems like the leading zeroes shouldn't be there.

It also makes Shortest mode a bit annoying because you can't do certain tricks involving "eval" anymore because eval treats a leading "0" as an indicator that the string should be interpreted as 'octal' in Ruby.

I think this clash would be better if you removed the leading zeroes.
I personally consider this way too easy. I normally wouldn't make a fuss about it, but I always complain when they're way too hard, so it's only fair to mention it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is understandable at once, comfortable in all languages. easy for beginners. great work!

That seems an appropriate problem in clash.
Good !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy enough for all languages, this is a good candidate for faster/reverse clashing mode
Too easy in this scenario. Would be better if you want to have "no" with the capacity reached in the maximum time allowed and "yes" with the time used to fill its tank ( rounded to 1 point digit ).
No tests end when the spaceship fills up exactly as the time runs out. I'd recommend adding a test like that. Otherwise, fun and simple problem. I would approve if I knew how :P

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's simple and easy once the calculation is figured out, good for starters.
Nice and easy, good for starters!

I get the idea and the statement is clear, but I think this is a little too easy. Maybe you could add an element where there is a maximum amount of time to fuel the ship and the answer is "yes" or "no" if the ship can be fueled or not.

Also validators need to be different from tests.
Thanks for the feedback! I'll see if I can incorporate something like that into it.
Thanks for the feedback! Added a test like that.
